Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Preface

The objective of this standard is to explain the basis and general rulings for Sharikat al-’Aqd, (contractual partnership) which is known today as Musharakah, including the rulings for joint partnership, reputation (cred- itworthiness) partnership, vocation partnership, diminishing partnership and modern corporations. The explanation of these partnerships includes definitions, rulings applicable to each partnership and the Shari’ah lim- itations that must be taken into account by Islamic financial Institutions (Institution/Institutions). (1) The word (Institution/Institutions) is used here to refer, in short, to Islamic financial institutions including Islamic Banks.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 1. Scope of the Standard

This standard covers all forms of traditional Fiqh-nominate partnerships that operate on the basis of Sharikat al-’Aqd (contractual partnership), except the partnerships that are explicitly excluded by this standard as indicated below. The standard also applies to all modern forms of partnerships including diminishing Musharakah. The standard does not cover ownership partnership where the parties jointly own an asset...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 2. Definition, Classifications and Types of Sharikat al-’Aqd > 2/1 Definition of Sharikat al-’Aqd

Sharikat al-’Aqd (contractual partnership) means an agreement between two or more parties to combine their assets, labour or liabilities for the purpose of making profits.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 2. Definition, Classifications and Types of Sharikat al-’Aqd > 2/2 Classifications of Sharikat al-’Aqd > 2/2/1 Traditional Fiqh-nominate partnerships

a) Sharikat al-’Inan (contractual partnership) b) Sharikat al-Wujuh or Al-Dhimam, i.e. partnership of creditworthiness or reputation (liability partnership) c) Sharikat al-A’mal (vocational partnerships and partnerships for undertaking difficult work or accepting jobs)

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 2. Definition, Classifications and Types of Sharikat al-’Aqd > 2/2 Classifications of Sharikat al-’Aqd > 2/2/2 Modern Corporations

a) Stock company b) Joint-liability company c) Partnership in commendum d) Company limited by shares e) Allotment (Muhassah) partnership f) Diminishing partnership (this partnership has originated from Sharikat al-’Inan)

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/1 Conclusion of a Sharikah contract > 3/1/1/1 Offer and acceptance

A Sharikah contract can be concluded by agreement between the parties concerned on the basis of offer and acceptance...

It is permissible for the Institution to enter into a partnership contract with non-Muslims...

First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/1 Conclusion of a Sharikah contract > 3/1/1/3 Syndicated financing with conventional banks

It is permissible for the Institutions to include conventional banks as partners in a syndicated financing...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/1 Conclusion of a Sharikah contract > 3/1/1/4 Amending partnership contract terms

It is permissible for the partners to amend at any point of time the terms of a partnership contract...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/2 The capital of Sharikah > 3/1/2/1 Monetary assets as capital

In principle, the capital of Sharikah should be contributed in the form of monetary assets...

First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/2 The capital of Sharikah > 3/1/2/2 Different currencies in partnership capital

If partners have contributed their partnership capital in different currencies...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/2 The capital of Sharikah > 3/1/2/3 Determination of partner's share in capital

The share of each partner in the capital should be determined...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/2 The capital of Sharikah > 3/1/2/4 Debts in Sharikah capital

It is not permitted that debts (receivables) alone be used as a contribution to the Sharikah capital...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/2 The capital of Sharikah > 3/1/2/5 Current account funds

The funds of current accounts, although they are juristically classified as loans to the Institutions...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/3 Managing a Sharikah venture > 3/1/3/1 Partner's rights

In principle, each partner is entitled to act in the interest of the partnership...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/3 Managing a Sharikah venture > 3/1/3/2 Management restriction

It is permissible for the partners to agree that the management of the partnership will be restricted...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/3 Managing a Sharikah venture > 3/1/3/3 Appointment of manager

It is permissible for the partners to appoint a manager other than one of the partners...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/3 Managing a Sharikah venture > 3/1/3/4 Remuneration for partner manager

It is not permitted, in a Sharikah contract, to specify a fixed remuneration for a partner...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/3 Managing a Sharikah venture > 3/1/3/5 Independent service contract

It is permissible that one of the partners be appointed to provide services that are mentioned...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/4 Guarantees in a Sharikah contract > 3/1/4/1 Trust basis for assets

All partners in a Sharikah contract maintain the assets of the Sharikah on a trust basis...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/4 Guarantees in a Sharikah contract > 3/1/4/2 Partner providing guarantees

It is permissible for a partner in a Sharikah contract to stipulate that another partner provides...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/4 Guarantees in a Sharikah contract > 3/1/4/3 Third-party guarantees

A third party may provide a guarantee to make up a loss of capital...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/1 Profit sharing provision

The Sharikah contract should incorporate a provision specifying the manner of sharing profits...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/2 Determination of profit percentages

It is not permitted to defer the determination of the profit percentages...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/3 Profit proportional to capital contribution

In principle, the shares of profit may be in proportion to the percentage of each partner’s contribution...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/4 Proportions of losses

It is a requirement that the proportions of losses borne by partners be commensurate...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/5 Allocation methods

It is permissible for the partners to agree on the adoption of any method of allocation of profit...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/6 Deducting expenses before profit allocation

It is not permitted to start the allocation of profit between the partners unless the operating costs...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/7 Preclusion from profit sharing

It is not permitted that the conditions or modes of profit allocation include any clause...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/8 Profit exceeding a ceiling

It is permissible to agree that if the profit realised is above a certain ceiling...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/9 Final profit distribution

The profit may be finally distributed on the basis of the proceeds of selling all existing assets...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/10 Expected profit

It is not permitted that the final allocation of profit takes place based on expected profit...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/11 Funds on account

It is permissible to allocate some funds to any of the partners on account...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/12 Revenue from leasing

If the subject matter of Sharikah is assets acquired for leasing that bring in income...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/13 Profit reservation

It is permissible, based on the articles of association or a decision of the partners...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/5 The outcome of Sharikah investments (profit and loss) > 3/1/5/14 Charitable donation

It is permissible to agree on setting aside a proportion of profit for non-partners as a charitable donation.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/6 Maturity of Sharikah > 3/1/6/1 Termination rights

Each partner is entitled to terminate the Sharikah after giving due notice...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/6 Maturity of Sharikah > 3/1/6/2 Binding purchase promise

It is permissible for a partner to issue a binding promise to buy...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3. First Category: Traditional Fiqh-Nominate Partnerships > 3/1 General rulings for Sharikah, especially Sharikat al-’Inan > 3/1/6 Maturity of Sharikah > 3/1/6/3 Sharikah end

A Sharikah venture comes to an end at the expiry date or before the expiry date...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3/2 Partnership in creditworthiness (liability partnership) > 3/2/1 Definition and obligations

A partnership in creditworthiness (partnership of liability) is a bilateral agreement between two or more parties to buy assets on credit based on reputation for profit. Partners agree on profit and liability sharing ratios.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3/2 Partnership in creditworthiness (liability partnership) > 3/2/2 Capital and liability

The partnership in creditworthiness has no monetary capital. The subject is an obligation or liability contingent on creditworthiness. Partners agree on liability ratios for debts.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3/2 Partnership in creditworthiness (liability partnership) > 3/2/3 Profit and loss distribution

Profit is distributed as agreed. Loss is borne by partners according to the liability ratio. Lump sum profit provision for a partner is not permitted.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3/3 Service partnerships > 3/3/1 Definition and profit sharing

A service partnership is an agreement to provide services or manufacture goods with profit sharing based on an agreed ratio.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3/3 Service partnerships > 3/3/2 Capital and service distribution

Service partnerships have no monetary capital. Partners may distribute different services among themselves to achieve the partnership's purpose.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3/3 Service partnerships > 3/3/3 Profit and lump sum restrictions

Profit is distributed according to agreed ratios. Contracts should not specify lump sum payments to particular partners.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 3/3 Service partnerships > 3/3/4 Capital goods

If capital goods are required, partners may contribute funds or provide them directly. Fees for providing capital goods can be charged as expenses.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/1 Definition

A stock company is a company with capital partitioned into tradable shares, with limited shareholder liability. It has a juristic personality through incorporation by law.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/1 Contract binding and share transfer

The stock company contract is binding for the specified duration. Shareholders cannot unilaterally dissolve but can sell shares.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/2 Share value adjustments

Permitted to add a percentage to share value for issuing expenses, appropriately estimated.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/3 New share issuance

Permissible to issue new shares at fair value, premium, or discount, based on asset valuation.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/4 Underwriting shares

Shareholder can underwrite shares without consideration, except for services like feasibility studies or marketing.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/5 Instalment payments

Payment for shares can be in instalments, forming part of the capital, provided all shares and liability are covered.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/6 Interest-based loans

Buying shares with interest-based loans is not permissible.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/7 Selling shares not owned

Selling shares not owned is impermissible, even with broker promises.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/8 Trading regulations

Authorities can organize share trading through licensed brokers.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/9 Limited liability disclosure

Publish the company's liability limitation to inform customers.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/10 Share sale regulations

Share sales must follow company regulations not conflicting with Shari'ah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/11 Mortgaging shares

Permissibility of mortgaging company shares subject to rules.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/12 Nominative shares

Permissible to issue 'to the order of' shares.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/13 Bearer shares

Permissible to issue bearer shares with rights vesting in the certificate holder.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/14 Preference shares

Issuing preference shares with special financial characteristics is not permitted.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/1 Stock company > 4/1/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/1/2/15 Tamattu' (enjoyment) shares

Issuing Tamattu' shares, which partake in profit but lack voting rights, is not permitted.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/2 Joint-liability company > 4/2/1 Definition

A joint-liability company is a personal partnership publicly declared with joint liability of partners.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/2 Joint-liability company > 4/2/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/2/2/1 Creditor rights

Creditors can claim from any partner for company obligations.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/2 Joint-liability company > 4/2/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/2/2/2 Partner withdrawal

Partners may withdraw if no company duration is set, with notification, and without harm.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/2 Joint-liability company > 4/2/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/2/2/3 Substitution restriction

Partners cannot bring substitutes without agreement.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/3 Partnership in commendum > 4/3/1 Definition

Partnership in commendum involves managing and sleeping partners, with limited liability for sleeping partners.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/3 Partnership in commendum > 4/3/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/3/2/1 Profit and loss allocation

Profit distributed by lots; losses shared by partners based on capital ratio.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/3 Partnership in commendum > 4/3/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/3/2/2 Profit restriction

Sleeping partner cannot receive profit based on capital percentage or lump sum.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/4 Company limited by shares > 4/4/1 Definition

A company limited by shares is a personal partnership with managing and sleeping partners, with liability based on shareholding.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/4 Company limited by shares > 4/4/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/4/2/1 Liability and management

Managing partners have joint liability; sleeping partners' liability limited to shares.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/4 Company limited by shares > 4/4/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/4/2/2 Sleeping partner restrictions

Sleeping partners cannot manage; their involvement limited to shareholding.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/4 Company limited by shares > 4/4/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/4/2/3 Management delegation

Company management may be delegated to a managing partner or third party.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/4 Company limited by shares > 4/4/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/4/2/4 Profit and loss distribution

Profit distributed by participation ratio; losses borne by partners based on shares.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/4 Company limited by shares > 4/4/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/4/2/5 Sleeping partner profit restriction

Sleeping partner cannot receive profit based on capital percentage or lump sum.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/5 Allotment/particular (Muhassah) partnership > 4/5/1 Definition

An allotment partnership belongs to the personal form of company, without a juristic personality.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/5 Allotment/particular (Muhassah) partnership > 4/5/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/5/2/1 Rulings alignment

Muhassah companies follow 'Inan partnership rulings.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/5 Allotment/particular (Muhassah) partnership > 4/5/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/5/2/2 Personal liability

Partners are personally liable for company liabilities.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/5 Allotment/particular (Muhassah) partnership > 4/5/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/5/2/3 Non-binding contract

Partnership contract is not binding unless agreed otherwise.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4 Modern Corporations > 4/5 Allotment/particular (Muhassah) partnership > 4/5/2 Shari'ah Rulings > 4/5/2/4 Withdrawal conditions

A partner can withdraw upon notification without causing harm.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/1 Definition

Diminishing Musharakah is a partnership where one partner promises to buy the equity share of the other.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4/5/1/2 Sharikat al-Muhassah

Sharikat al-Muhassah has no juristic personality because people other than the partners do not know about it. This partnership does not have any separate financial liability as an entity.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4/5/2 Shari’ah rulings relating to Muhassah Company > 4/5/2/1 Rulings for Muhassah and 'Inan partnership

The rulings for and basis of a Muhassah company do not differ from those for an ’Inan partnership.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4/5/2 Shari’ah rulings relating to Muhassah Company > 4/5/2/2 Personal liability of partners

The liability of partners is personal and, as such, they are liable for the liabilities of the company from their personal assets.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4/5/2 Shari’ah rulings relating to Muhassah Company > 4/5/2/3 Contract binding nature

The contract of a Muhassah partnership is not binding. However, if the parties agree to make it binding for a particular period of time, then they shall be bound by such an agreement.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 4/5/2 Shari’ah rulings relating to Muhassah Company > 4/5/2/4 Termination of partnership

A partner in Sharikat al-Muhassah is entitled to terminate his partnership on condition that (I) he notifies other partners of his intention to withdraw and (II) the unilateral withdrawal from partnership would not cause damage to other partners or clients of the company.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/1 Definition of Diminishing Musharakah

Diminishing Musharakah is a form of partnership in which one of the partners promises to buy the equity share of the other partner gradually until the title to the equity is completely transferred to him.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/2 General rules for Diminishing Musharakah

The general rules for partnerships must be applied to a diminishing partnership, especially the rules for Sharikat al-’Inan.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/3 Cost of insurance or maintenance

It is not permitted to stipulate that one partner should bear all the cost of insurance or maintenance on the ground that he will eventually own the subject matter of the partnership.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/4 Capital contribution

Each partner should contribute part of the capital. The contribution may be in the form of cash or tangible assets that can be translated into a monetary value.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/5 Profit sharing

The ratio of profit or income of the partnership that each partner (the Institution and customer) is entitled to should be clearly determined.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/6 Lump sum from profits

It is not permitted to stipulate that one partner has a right to receive a lump sum out of the profits.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/7 Equity share acquisition promise

It is permissible for one of the partners to give a binding promise that entitles the other partner to acquire his equity share gradually, but not at their original or face value.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/8 Acquisition arrangement

The partners may arrange for the acquisition of the equity share of the Institution in a manner that serves the interests of both parties.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 5 Diminishing Musharakah > 5/9 Renting or leasing partner's share

It is permissible for either of the partners to rent or to lease the share of the other partner for a specified amount and duration.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > 6 Date of Issuance of the Standard

This Standard was issued on 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 16 May 2002 A.D.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/1_permissibility_of_partnership

The Fuqaha have classified partnerships into four categories, namely Sharikat al-’Inan (contractual partnership), Sharikat al-Abdan (skilled trade partnership), Sharikat al-Mufawadah (agency-like partnership) and Sharikat al-Wujuh (creditworthiness or reputation partnership). The most important of all is Sharikat al- ’Inan (contractual partnership). The permissibility of this form of partnership is established by the Qur`an, the Sunnah and practical consensus of the Fuqaha...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/2_conclusion_of_sharikah_contract

It is permitted to conclude a partnership contract with non-Muslims or conventional banks for carrying out permissible operations in association with necessary guarantees that they will observe Shari’ah precepts and principles...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/3_capital_of_sharikah

The basis for the permissibility that Sharikah capital may be contributed in the form of tangible assets other than cash, after valuation...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/4_managing_a_partnership

The basis for the right of each partner to participate in the management of the partnership is that partnership is based on elements of agency and trust...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/5_guarantees_in_partnership

The basis of the requirement that a partner is not liable except in cases of misconduct or negligence...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/6_outcome_of_partnership_investment

The basis for the impermissibility of an agreement to determine the profit share on the basis of a lump sum or a percentage of the capital...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/7_termination_of_partnership

The basis for the rule that termination of partnership will not affect obligations and actions that took place before it...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/8_modern_corporations

The permissibility of modern corporations is dependent on the principle of Shari’ah that human transactions are, in principle, permissible...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 1/9_stock_companies

The basis for the permissibility of underwriting issues of shares without taking consideration is that this is an undertaking that does not involve an impermissible act...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 2/1_joint_liability_company

The basis for the permissibility of the undertaking of partners in a joint liability company to be jointly responsible...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 2/2_partnership_in_commendum

The basis for the impermissibility of sleeping partners of partnership in commendum or company limited by shares being entitled to interfere in the management...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 3_allotment_particular_partnership

The basis for the permissibility of unilateral termination of participation in this kind of partnership by any of the partners...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > appendix_b_shariah_basis_for_the_standard > 4_diminishing_partnership

The basis for saying that all the general rules for partnerships, especially the rules for ’Inan partnership, are applicable to diminishing partnerships...

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) > Definitions > Contract Partnership (Sharikat al-’Aqd)

Contract partnership is an agreement between two or more parties to combine their assets or to merge their services or obligations and liabilities with the aim of making profit.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) > Definitions > Partnership of Ownership (Sharikat al-Milk)

Partnership of ownership (Sharikat al-Milk) is the combination of the assets of two or more persons in a manner that creates a state of sharing the realised profit or income or benefiting from an increase in the value of the partnership assets. This combination of assets for making profit necessitates bearing losses, if any. The ownership partnership is created by events beyond the partners’ control such as the inheritance rights of heirs in the legacy of a deceased person. This partnership is also created by the wish of the partners such as when two or more parties acquire common shares in a particular asset.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) > Definitions > Mufawadah Partnership

Mufawadah partnership is any partnership in which the parties are equal in all respects, such as funds contributed by them, their right to act and their liability, from the commencement of the partnership to the date of its termination.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) > Definitions > Sharecropping Partnership (Muzara’ah)

Sharecropping is partnership in crops in which one party presents land to another for cultivation and maintenance in consideration for a common defined share in the crop.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) > Definitions > Irrigating Partnership (Musaqat)

Irrigating partnership is a partnership that depends on one party presenting designated plants/trees that produce edible fruits to another in order to work on their irrigation in consideration for a common defined share in the fruits.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) > Definitions > Agricultural Partnership (Mugharasah)

Agricultural partnership is a partnership in which one party presents a treeless piece of land to another to plant trees on it on the condition that they share the trees and fruits in accordance with a defined percentage.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) > Definitions > Distribution of Proceeds and Profits

Distribution of proceeds and profits is a process of termination an undivided ownership in the company by the final distribution of the assets whereby rights of each partner are defined and common shares are partitioned into identified sets for each partner. This is why distribution is defined as identification of undefined shares or proceeds of a particular person.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Preface

The aim of this standard is to explain the Shari’ah rulings for restricted and unrestricted Mudarabah, whether the Islamic financial Institution is acting in the capacity of a Mudarib (entrepreneur) or in the capacity of an investor.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 1. Scope of the Standard

This standard covers Mudarabah contracts between the Institution and other entities or individuals. It also covers joint investment accounts and special purpose investment accounts based on Mudarabah. It does not cover Sukuk of Mudarabah or other partnership contracts.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 2. Definition of Mudarabah

Mudarabah is a partnership in profit where one party provides capital (Rab al-Mal) and the other party provides labour (Mudarib).

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 3. Agreement of Mudarabah Financing > 3/1 Permissibility

It is permissible to conclude Mudarabah financing contracts for a specific sum and duration based on a general framework or memorandum of understanding.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 3. Agreement of Mudarabah Financing > 3/2 Memorandum Details

The memorandum should define the contractual framework, intention of using unrestricted or restricted Mudarabah, profit ratio, and types of guarantees.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 3. Agreement of Mudarabah Financing > 3/3 Integral Part of Contract

If a Mudarabah contract is concluded based on the memorandum, it becomes an integral part unless agreed otherwise.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 4. Mudarabah Contract > 4/1 Contract Terminology

The Mudarabah contract may use terms like Mudarabah, Qirad or Mu’amalah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 4. Mudarabah Contract > 4/2 Legal Capacity Requirement

Both parties must have the legal capacity to appoint agents and accept agency.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 4. Mudarabah Contract > 4/3 Binding Nature

A Mudarabah contract is not binding, except when the Mudarib has commenced the business or if a duration is agreed.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 4. Mudarabah Contract > 4/4 Trust-Based Contract

The Mudarib is not liable for losses unless there is misconduct, negligence, or breach of trust.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 5. Types of Mudarabah > 5/1 Unrestricted Mudarabah

In unrestricted Mudarabah, the Mudarib has freedom to trade but must act in party's interest.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 5. Types of Mudarabah > 5/2 Restricted Mudarabah

In restricted Mudarabah, the Mudarib's actions are limited to certain locations or types of investment.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 6. Guarantees in a Mudarabah Contract

Guarantees are permissible to cover misconduct, negligence, or breach of contract by the Mudarib.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 7. Requirements Relating to the Capital > 7/1 Form of Capital

Capital must be in cash or tangible assets, the value of which is agreed or appraised.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 7. Requirements Relating to the Capital > 7/2 Clarity of Capital

The capital should be clearly known, defined in terms of quality and quantity.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 7. Requirements Relating to the Capital > 7/3 Debt as Capital

Debts cannot be used as capital in a Mudarabah contract.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 7. Requirements Relating to the Capital > 7/4 Control of Capital

Capital must be put at the disposal of the Mudarib for the contract to be valid.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/1 Profit Distribution Mechanism

The profit distribution mechanism must be clear and based on agreed percentages.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/2 Additional Profit and Fees

A profit share in addition to a fee is not permissible unless for activities outside Mudarabah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/3 Agreed Profit Ratios

Parties agree on profit ratios which can be changed anytime through mutual agreement.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/4 Customary Profit Distribution

If not stipulated, customary practice may determine profit shares.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/5 Stipulation of Lump Sum

Stipulation of a lump sum for profit renders the contract void.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/6 Profit Assignment Restrictions

Profit assignment to separate capitals or periods is not permissible.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/7 Condition of Capital Maintenance

Profit cannot be claimed unless the capital is maintained intact.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/8 Entitlement to Profit

Mudarib’s entitlement to profit is realized upon recognition, subject to interim profits for capital protection.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 8. Rulings and Requirements Relating to Profit > 8/9 Commingling of Funds

Mudarib’s own funds mixed with Mudarabah funds affect profit distribution proportions.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > 9/1 Unrestricted Duties

Mudarib can operate freely in permissible activities and appoint others if necessary.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > 9/2 Permissible Restrictions

Capital provider may impose location, time, or sector restrictions on Mudarib's operations.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > 9/3 Capital Provider's Stipulations

Capital provider cannot stipulate involvement in Mudarib’s operations or restrict Mudarib’s actions unnecessarily.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > 9/4 Standard Responsibilities

Mudarib responsible for customary asset management tasks without additional fees.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > 9/5 Pricing Restrictions

Mudarib must trade at market prices unless benefits to Mudarabah are clear.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > 9/6 Loan and Donation Prohibition

Loans or donations from Mudarabah funds are not permissible without consent.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 9. Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > 9/7 Expense Rights

Mudarib may receive living and traveling expenses with prior approval or as per custom.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 10. Liquidation of a Mudarabah Contract > 10/1 Methods of Liquidation

A Mudarabah can be liquidated through unilateral termination, mutual agreement, maturity date, exhaustion of funds, or death of the Mudarib.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 10. Liquidation of a Mudarabah Contract > 10/2 Maturity Procedure

Assets must be liquidated as per profits distribution protocols on maturity.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > 11. Date of Issuance of the Standard

This Standard was issued on 4 Rabi’ I, 1424 A.H., corresponding to 16 May 2002 A.D.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Statement of the Standard > Adoption of the Standard

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Introduction

Shari’ah Standard No. 13: Mudarabah

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/1/1: Initial Decision

In its meeting No. (5) held in Makkah Al-Mukarramah during the period of 8-12 Ramadan 1421 A.H., corresponding to 4-8 December 2001 A.D., the Shari’ah Board decided to give priority to the preparation of a Shari’ah Standard on Mudarabah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/1/2: Consultant Commissioning

On Saturday 15 Dhul-Hajjah 1421 A.H., corresponding to 10 March 2001 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee recommended to the Shari’ah Board the commissioning of a Shari’ah consultant to prepare a juristic study and an exposure draft on the Shari’ah Standard for Mudarabah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/1/3: Draft Discussion and Amendments

In its meeting held on 18 Muharram 1422 A.H., corresponding to 12 April 2001 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee discussed the exposure draft of the Shari’ah Rules for Mudarabah and asked the consultant to make amendments in light of the comments made by the members.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/1/4: Further Revisions

The Committee also held a meeting on 20 Jumada II, 1422 A.H., corresponding to 8 December 2001 A.D., and made some amendments in light of the comments made by the members.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/2: Presentation to Shari’ah Board

The revised exposure draft of the Standard was presented to the Shari’ah Board in its 7th meeting held in Makkah Al-Mukarramah during the period of 9-13 Ramadan 1422 A.H., corresponding to 24-28 November 2001 A.D. The Shari’ah Board made further amendments to the exposure draft of the Standard and decided that it should be distributed to specialists and interested parties in order to obtain their comments with the objective of discussing them in a public hearing.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/3: Public Hearing

A public hearing was held in Bahrain during the period of 29-20 Dhul-Hajjah 1422 A.H., corresponding to 2-3 February 2002 A.D. The public hearing was attended by more than thirty participants representing central Institutions, Institutions, accounting firms, Shari’ah scholars, academics and others who are interested in this field.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/4: Committee Discussion and Amendments

The Shari’ah Standards Committee in its meeting held during the period of 21-22 Dhul-Hajjah 1422 A.H., corresponding to 6-7 March 2002 A.D., in the Kingdom of Bahrain discussed the comments made on the exposure draft. The Committee made the amendments which it considered necessary in light of both the discussions that had taken place in the public hearing and the written comments that had been received.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/5: Final Shari’ah Board Review

The Shari’ah Board in its 8th meeting held on 28 Safar - 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 11-16 May 2002 A.D., in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah discussed the amendments made by the Shari’ah Standards Committee, and made the necessary amendments, which it deemed necessary. Some paragraphs of the standard were adopted by the unanimous vote of the members of the Shari’ah Board, while the other paragraphs were adopted by the majority vote of the members.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/6: Shari’ah Standards Review Committee

The Shari’ah Standards Review Committee reviewed the Standard in its meeting held on Rabi’ II, 1433 A.H., corresponding to March 2012 A.D., in the State of Qatar, and proposed after deliberation a set of amendments (additions, deletions, and rephrasing) as deemed necessary, and then submitted the proposed amendments to the Shari’ah Board for approval.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix A: Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 5/7: Final Approval

In its 41st meeting held in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia during the period of 27-29 Sha’ban 1436 A.H., corresponding to 14-16 June 2015 A.D., the Shari’ah Board discussed the proposed amendments submitted by the Shari’ah Standards Review Committee. After deliberation, the Shari’ah Board approved necessary amendments, and the Standard was adopted in its current amended version.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Permissibility of Mudarabah and Its Rationale > Permissibility from Qur'an

Mudarabah contract derives its permissibility from the Qur’an: {“Others travelling through the land, seeking of Allah’s bounty”}. This verse is interpreted to mean those who travel for the purpose of trading and seeking permissible income.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Permissibility of Mudarabah and Its Rationale > Permissibility from Sunnah

The Hadith of Al-’Abbas Ibn Abdul-Muttalib and others support the permissibility of Mudarabah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Permissibility of Mudarabah and Its Rationale > Consensus Among Scholars

There is generally consensus among the scholars in respect to the permissibility of a Mudarabah contract.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Permissibility of Mudarabah and Its Rationale > Rationale for Permissibility

Money cannot increase unless associated with work. Mudarabah facilitates cooperation between those with capital and those with business expertise.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Contract of Mudarabah > Legal Capability and Agency

Both parties must be legally capable to appoint, or act as, an agent since each acts as an agent of the other.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Contract of Mudarabah > Non-binding Nature Initially

The Mudarabah contract is initially non-binding because the Mudarib is merely an agent.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Contract of Mudarabah > Binding Nature After Commencement

Once work has commenced, the Mudarabah contract becomes binding to prevent loss to the Mudarib.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Contract of Mudarabah > Time Limitation

A time limit for the Mudarabah operation is permissible as it relates to agency contracts with designated durations.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Contract of Mudarabah > Trustee Role of Mudarib

The Mudarib is considered a trustee for the Mudarabah funds. The Mudarib and the owner share benefits, and the risks are borne by the funds.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Guarantees in a Mudarabah Contract

Guarantees are allowed in case of misconduct and negligence of the Mudarib, as they then become liable for losses.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Requirements Relating to the Capital > Capital in Tangible Assets

The capital may be constituted by tangible assets to achieve profit.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Requirements Relating to the Capital > Known Amount

The capital amount must be clearly known to avoid uncertainty or ambiguity.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Requirements Relating to the Capital > Debt as Capital

A debt owed by the Mudarib cannot be contributed as it is not available for use.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Requirements Relating to the Capital > Capital Presentation

The capital must be presented to the Mudarib to manage and achieve the Mudarabah objective.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Rules and Requirements Relating to Profit > Profit Ratio

The profit ratio must be known as it is the subject matter of a Mudarabah contract.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Rules and Requirements Relating to Profit > Profit Share

The profit share must be a percentage of profit, not a lump sum.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Rules and Requirements Relating to Profit > Simultaneous Profit and Fee

Impermissible to receive both profit share and fee as it precludes sharing profit.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Rules and Requirements Relating to Profit > Changing Profit Ratio

Agreement to change profit distribution is permissible as it does not preclude profit sharing.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Rules and Requirements Relating to Profit > Silent Profit Ratio

Contract is nullified if silent on profit ratio and no customary distribution practice exists.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > Freedom of Action

In an unrestricted Mudarabah, the Mudarib is allowed freedom of action to achieve profit.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > No Stipulation by Capital Provider

The capital provider cannot stipulate a right to work with the Mudarib or interfere with Mudarabah operations.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Duties and Powers of the Mudarib > Use of Funds for Loans or Donations

The Mudarib cannot make loans or donations from Mudarabah funds as it does not benefit the operation.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Liquidation of Mudarabah Contract > Unilateral or Agreement Liquidation

Allowed to liquidate Mudarabah unilaterally, by agreement, or at maturity date.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Liquidation of Mudarabah Contract > Loss of Capital

Termination permitted if capital is lost as it cannot be worked.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (B) - The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > Liquidation of Mudarabah Contract > Death of Mudarib

Termination is allowed if the Mudarib dies, similar to an agency contract.

Shari’ah Standard No. (12) - Sharikah (Musharakah) and Modern Corporations (Revised Standard) > Appendix (C) - Definitions > Differences Between Mudarabah and Sharikah

Mudarabah involves both capital and work by Mudarib, whereas Sharikah involves joint capital contribution.
